title.narrative: CoE Enhancing Effectiveness of Civil Monitoring Boards with European Standards
Stärkt effektivitet i civila insynskommittéer i linje med europeisk standard

description.narrative:
Europarådet har ansökt om bidrag från Sida om 8 600 000 SEK för att kunna genomföra en insats för att öka effektiviteten i de civila insynskommittéerna (civil monitoring boards) med uppgift att utöva tillsyn i turkiska fängelser och häkten i linje med europeisk standard under perioden juni 2019 till maj 2022. Kvalitén och effektiviteten i kommittéerna har kritiserats i EU:s årliga framstegsrapporter om Turkiet.
Insatsen syftar till att bidra till ett tryggare samhälle som skyddar de mänskliga rättigheterna för frihetsberövade personer genom att stärka insynen i fängelser/häkten genom att använda Europarådets standards och god praxis.
Självständigheten och effektiviteten hos dessa civila insynskommittéer ska stärkas genom förbättra objektiviteten och transparensen i deras arbete. Kommitté-medlemmarna ska få tillgång till utbildning och förbättrad samordning dem emellan för att öka kvalitén i detta system för medborgerlig insyn.
Insatsens totala budget är 1 600 000 EUR. Turkiska justitieministeriet skall bidra med 200 000 EUR, Europarådets fond for mänskliga rättigheter bidrar med 324 000 EUR, Schweiz bidrar med 200 000 CHF, Kanada bidrar med 50 000 EUR.

The Council of Europe has applied to Sida for funding of 8 600 000 SEK SEK to carry out the programme "CoE Enhancing the Effectiveness of Civil Monitoring Boards (CMBs) in line with European Standards" in Turkey during the period June 2019 to May 2022. The quality and effectiveness of the CBMs have been critizised in the EUs yearly progress reports.
The CBMs are established in Turkish law as a mechanism of civilian oversight of conditions in Trukish prisons and detention centerns. The intervention aims to contribute to a safer society that provides full protection of the rights and dignity of persons deprived of their liberty by enhancing the prison monitoring practices in Turkey applying Council of Europe standards and best practices
The independence and efficiency of the CMBs will be further strengthened, improving the objectiveness and transparency in prison monitoring. CMB members will benefit from sustainable training provision and internal coordination, improving the quality of the civic monitoring system
The intervention’s total budget is 1 600 000 EUR, out of which the Turkish Ministry of Justice will contribute 200 000 EUR, the Human Rights Trust Fund of the Council of Europe will contribute 324 000 EUR, the Government of Switzerland will contribute 200 000 CHF, the Government of Canada will contribute 50 000 EUR.

The theory of change for the intervention is to attain independence and efficiency of CMB and increase their capacity on tools and mechanisms for an objective, transparent and quality civic monitoring. Objectives of intervention 1-The independence and efficiency of the CMBs further strengthened, improving the objectiveness and transparency in prison monitoring -The CMBs functional and operational independence enhanced in line with the international standards by revising its regulatory framework -The CMBs effectiveness improved by further developing, unifying and aligning their working methodology and tools with CoE standards and best European practices 2-CMB members benefit from sustainable training provision and internal coordination, improving the quality of the civic monitoring system -The capacities of the CMB members enhanced by increasing their knowledge and skills in conducting prison monitoring in line with the CoE standards and good European practices. -The CMBs internal coordination and communication with external control mechanisms improved.

description.narrative:
The project is on track with minor delays and is set to achieve its results. Certain activities were hampered by the Covid outbreak however CoE has adapted new working methods to mitigate risks and all has been functioning well.
The interest of CMB members is high while the ownership of the Directorate General for Prisons and Detention Houses (DGPDH) is also significant. The project also enjoys a vast member of stakeholders such as Ministry of Justice (MoJ) inspectors, enforcement judges, public prosecutors, National Preventive Mechanism (NPM) and their involvement is also notable. The dialogue with civil society is assessed to be low.
1-The independence and efficiency of the CMBs further strengthened, improving the objectiveness and transparency in prison monitoring
Several Roundtable meetings were carried out these were:
Discussions on the international standards and best practices regarding efficient prison monitoring.
Drafting process of the CMBs monitoring standards and tools was completed after a RT meeting at which beneficiaries and project stakeholders provided their feedback. a general comprehensive prison monitoring checklist with separate chapters for certain categories of inmates in addition to the checklist, detailed questionnaires were prepared. The checklist also has annexes on: CMBs methodology for conducting prison visits, reporting template and compilation of international standards on prison monitoring. 395 CMB members were informed on the checklist and workshop was held in Ankara Sincan prison. Women's, children and foreign prisoners were the subject of study for the workshop. 2 more workshops is expected to be held in other prisons.
Proposal on amending the legislative framework towards enhancing CMBs independence and efficiency was finalised after a RT meeting attended by all relevant stakeholders who provided their comments and suggestions. The framework features mandate of the CMBs, gender quota, consultations with civil society, publication of the reports, internal coordination and training of the CMBs, as well as a follow up procedure to the prison visits. Article 6 of the draft proposal on the Law that extends the work of CMB to detention/transport vehicles and places in scope to health has been enacted although the whole of the draft work is waiting for adoption. The regulation is also on hold as the Ministry is waiting for the adoption of other articles of the Law to enact the Regulation.
2-CMB members benefit from sustainable training provision and internal coordination, improving the quality of the civic monitoring system
Steps for further improvement of the CMBs internal coordination and communication continued to be undertaken by developing the web-based platform that will serve as the main tool in ensuring internal exchanges and unified methods of work.
Cooperation and coordination between the different mechanisms conducting monitoring visits and inspections to prisons in Turkey was further improved by various roundtable meetings and discussions. The website is expected to further contribute to this. Discussion on the access to the website and materials to be open to members and general public is being debated.
The project continued to raising awareness among the stakeholders by distributing leaflets on the CMBs mandate and functioning and on importance of their role in the penitentiary system. The leaflets started to be distributed to courthouses, prisons, bar associations, medical chambers, civil society organisations, and other external prison monitoring mechanisms to reach the widest audience possible. Different types of leaflets are prepared to different actors (prisoners, prison personnel, etc.) to increase their interest on CMB's.
A total of 19 trainers including academics from the selected universities, lawyers, and representatives of DGPDH were trained in an online Training of Trainers (ToT) session, held on 30 November-1 December 2020, on the CoE programme for Human Rights Education for Legal Professionals (HELP) methodology. Seven different training modules were also prepared to enhance the skills and knowledge of CMB members to improve the monitoring process.
